questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to OPD complaining of progressive back pain over the past year. She also reports unintentional weight loss and occasional night sweats. Upon examination, she is neurologically intact but has some localized tenderness in the mid-thoracic spine. MRI with contrast demonstrates a large, uniformly enhancing epidural lesion with a significant amount of cord compression at T7 and some involvement of the posterolateral aspect of the vertebral body extending into the pedicle. Her intervertebral discs appear uninvolved. Initial blood tests are normal, including a white blood count of 7,200 WBCs/μL and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 5 mm/h (normal range 0–20). What is the next most appropriate step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Biopsy of the lesion The next most appropriate step is biopsy of the lesion The patient’s history is concerning for some type of neoplastic process. The MRI indicates an epidural lesion with bone involvement but no involvement of the discs . The MRI appearance of an epidural abscess is heterogeneously enhancing epidural collection that is isointense or hypointense on T1 images but hyperintense on T2 images. The likely diagnosis from the above scenario is suggestive of Epidural lymphoma.

Highyeild:

Epidural lymphoma appears isointense or hypointense on T1 and a hyperintense or hypointense appearance on T2. There tends to be uniform and diffuse gadolinium enhancement. When epidural lymphoma is suspected, tissue is needed to confirm and refine the diagnosis. Hence, a biopsy should be obtained. In this case, a biopsy of the pedicle/posterolateral vertebral body is likely.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION B. : Typical pyogenic infections usually start in the disc spaces. Thus, it would be unlikely that this patient has discitis. The features, in this case, are suggestive of Epidural lymphoma. Hence IV Antibiotics have no role. OPTION C. : The features, in this case, are suggestive of Epidural lymphoma. Hence CBC has no role; the ideal confirmatory test is a Biopsy of the lesion OPTION D. : Regarding irrigation and debridement , obtaining a diagnosis before initiating care would be preferable, especially given that the patient is neurologically intact and likely has a tumor.

Fallen fragment The given imaging reveals a fracture running through a central cystic lesion situated in the proximal humeral metaphysis and also shows a fallen fragment sign. This, along with the age predisposition, suggests a Unicameral bone cyst/Simple bone cyst.

questions.text: A patient presented in ORTHO OPD complaining of bony swelling in his knee. Radiological imaging was done and given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Osteochondroma Osteochondromas are common benign tumors. Many of the lesions cause no symptoms and are discovered accidentally. Sometimes, it develops pain due to the following reasons: Compression of the neurovascular bundle Fracture of the bony stalk Inflammation of the overlying bursa Malignant transformation

Highyeild:

OSTEOCHONDROMA Common; developmental anomaly (Not an actual tumor) Metaphysis→ Grows with skeleton No growth after skeletal maturity Pedunculated/ Sessile ↓ Stalk deviates away from the growth plate/joint Line Overlying cartilage > 2 cm: Malignant transformation Usually painless, but it can lead to sudden pain or complications ↓ Pathological # Aneurysm (false) Bursitis Malignant transformation Nerve compression Trevor's disease: Intra-articular epiphyseal osteochondroma Treatment: Wait/Watch Excision

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. – Osteosarcoma does not present as a pedunculated mass; it shows an aggressive periosteal reaction in the form of a sun ray appearance with cortical bone destruction Option C. – Chondroblastoma has well-circumscribed epiphyseal lytic lesions with cortical expansion and stippled calcifications. Option D. – Chondrosarcoma is a lytic or blastic lesion with thickened cortex

questions.text: A patient presented to ORTHO OPD with the following imaging. Diagnosis of Nonossifying fibroma was made. Which of the following is wrong regarding nonossifying fibroma?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a developmental defect in which a nest of fibrous tissue appears in bone and persists

options.label: B
options.text: The most ordinary sites are the metaphysis of long bones

options.label: C
options.text: There is a high risk of malignant transformation

options.label: D
options.text: If the defect is significant may require curettage and bone grafting

questions.correct_answer: C. There is a high risk of malignant transformation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

There is a high risk of malignant transformation There is no associated risk of malignant transformation in NOF.

Highyeild:

Histology: The defect is filled with spindle-shaped cells in a whorled or storiform pattern. Giant cells and foam cells are always present. X-ray: well-defined, lobulated lesion located eccentrically at the metaphysis Treatment: Dissolve spontaneously with skeletal maturity Curettage and bone grafting

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Nonossifying fibroma is a developmental defect in which a nest of fibrous tissue appears within the bone and persists for some years before ossifying Option B. The most familiar sites of NOF is the metaphysis of long bones Option D. Treatment of NOF is not usually preferred. But if the defect is substantial or has led to repeated fractures, it can be treated by curettage and bone grafting.

questions.text: A 46 years old patient presented to Ortho OPD with progressive pain in the thigh. X ray of her thigh is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fibrous Dysplasia The A bove X-ray show bending of the femur, known as Shepherd’s crook deformity. It is seen in fibrous dysplasia of the proximal femur. X-rays features of fibrous dysplasia It demonstrates a non-aggressive, well-circumscribed lesion with a characteristic ground-glass matrix. Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental disorder in which areas of trabecular bone are replaced by cellular fibrous tissue.

questions.text: A 12 yr old boy presents to the OPD with pain left hip region. The patient was diagnosed with a developmental abnormality of bone characterized by failure of production of normal lamellar bone. Histology shows typical “alphabet soup” or “Chinese letter pattern.” What bone pathology are we talking about?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fibrous dysplasia Developmental abnormality of bone with failure of the production of normal lamellar bone, on histology presence of trabeculae of osteoid and bone within the fibrous stroma are present in a disorganized manner, and their appearance has been likened to “alphabet soup” and “Chinese letters.”. All these are features of Fibrous dysplasia.
